evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scenario.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scenario is robust against alternative explanations, as evidenced by consistent patterns across multiple data sources and absence of contradicting factors.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal data, such as misaligned task execution and delayed information sharing.

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew is evident in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scenario.

assumptions: Crew communication and coordination is assessed based on reported interactions and lack of warnings
No overriding mechanical or environmental causes negate communication breakdown
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If mechanical or environmental factors were primary causes rather than crew communication

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 show lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during pushback, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew interactions and possible procedural deviations

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal data, such as misaligned task execution and delayed information sharing.

assumptions: The described behaviors in H8, H10, and H12 reflect communication/coordination breakdown rather than procedural deviation
No mechanical or environmental factors primarily caused the incident
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and aligned task execution among crew
If procedural deviations rather than communication failures were the primary cause

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 describe misaligned task execution and delayed information sharing among crew, supporting the claim of communication/coordination breakdown aligning with key features.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting whether actions were procedural deviations or communication breakdown

slot_statements.availability: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: Mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase is resistant to known defeaters.

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure is present in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: No hidden mechanical faults were reported or detected
Operator procedural deviation and communication breakdown are sufficient to explain the event
defeaters: Discovery of verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure
Physical evidence of equipment malfunction or bench checks confirming control failure

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H3, H8, H10, H12) indicates the pushback continued past the TRP due to operator actions and communication issues rather than mechanical or control failure, supporting procedural deviation and communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence; ambiguity in operator actions and communication

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset.

assumptions: The TRP marking described corresponds to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal dataset
No contradictory evidence about marking adequacy is present in the dataset

If procedural deviations fully explained the incident without reference to marking deficiencies

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is observed and documented within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase.

No mechanical faults were reported or evident in the evidence provided
defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults or equipment failure causing the pushback beyond TRP

If communication breakdown was documented as the primary cause

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12) documents the procedural deviation in pushback execution with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier despite operator actions and communications, supporting the claim. node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features and characteristics defined for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: The TRP marking described applies directly to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 context.
Crew statements about marking visibility and signaling reflect actual environmental conditions.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clear, visible, and unambiguous to all crew members, or if procedural non-compliance was clearly documented as the cause, this would change the assessment.

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal scope.

Crew communication and alert behavior impact the robustness of deficiency identification.

Discriminators favor procedural deviation over communication breakdown, environmental deficiency, or mechanical failure.

node.statement: The identification of procedural deviation in pushback execution is robust against potential counterarguments or alternative explanations within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_baseline_t3_prefinal context.

node.statement: Required environmental markings are not obscured or damaged

assumptions: Small size of TRP marking does not equate to obscured or damaged marking.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were physically obscured, damaged, or missing, or if crew reported inability to see the markings.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

If there was explicit evidence of communication failure or lack of access to communication channels

node.statement: Availability of qualified personnel to perform the pushback procedure

defeaters: If evidence showed unqualified personnel performing the pushback or lack of awareness of TRP markings
If mechanical faults or environmental deficiencies were documented affecting the pushback

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H2 show qualified personnel were present and involved in the pushback procedure, supporting availability of qualified personnel. H9 and H11 confirm qualifications and awareness of TRP, contradicting environmental or mechanical failure causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of personnel availability issues; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness but qualifications are clear.

node.statement: Availability of required pushback equipment at the time of operation

defeaters: If evidence showed mechanical faults with the tug or aircraft controls causing unintended movement
If environmental markings were inadequate or not visible, contributing to the incident
If communication failures between crew or operators caused the deviation

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct evidence (H1-H4, H8, H12) shows the tug instructor took control and continued pushback past the TRP without adequate stop despite signals and awareness, indicating procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown, environmental marking deficiency, or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of mechanical failure or environmental marking inadequacy; some ambiguity in communication effectiveness but outweighed by procedural control evidence.

node.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to communicate

assumptions: Communication via interphone and visual signals was effective and understood
No unreported incapacitation or communication barriers existed
defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were incapacitated or unable to communicate effectively
If communication devices had failed or were not used properly

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple evidence items (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) indicate that crew members were communicating and aware of the situation, with no indication of incapacitation or inability to communicate, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication failure or incapacitation; assumptions based on reported interactions

node.statement: Availability of clear communication channels between pushback team and flight crew

assumptions: Communication via interphone and headset operator is considered a clear communication channel.
Lack of warnings from wingman or headset operator implies procedural deviation rather than communication channel unavailability.
defeaters: If evidence showed explicit communication failure or lack of communication channels between pushback team and flight crew.
If headset operator or wingman had actively warned or intervened to prevent the collision.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, H11, and H12 show that communication channels existed but were insufficient or ineffective, supporting availability of communication but indicating procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in effectiveness of communication despite channel availability

node.statement: Required environmental markings are visible under current lighting and weather conditions

assumptions: The TRP markings described in H7 and H13 are representative of the current lighting and weather conditions
No other evidence contradicts the visibility of the environmental markings
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were obscured or not visible under current lighting and weather conditions
If crew reported inability to see or identify the TRP markings

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 describe the TRP marking location and visibility, indicating the required environmental markings were present and visible, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in subjective perception of marking visibility and size

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation
children_spec.test_procedure: Check communication logs and crew location data to verify if crew members were available and reachable at the time of the incident

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance records and device status reports to confirm that communication equipment was functional and accessible

children_spec.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to respond to communication attempts
children_spec.test_procedure: Review medical and incident reports to determine if any crew member was incapacitated or impaired during the event

node.statement: Required environmental markings are physically present at the location

assumptions: Physical presence of TRP marking implies availability; adequacy and visibility are separate issues.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP marking was missing or obscured, or if physical marking inadequacy was documented, the conclusion might change.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircrafts nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 confirm the TRP marking is physically present but small; H8, H10, and H12 indicate communication and procedural issues rather than marking absence, thus contradicting the claim that required markings are physically present.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marking adequacy and visibility; small size of TRP may affect effectiveness though physically present.

node.statement: Crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation

defeaters: If evidence showed crew members were not physically present or reachable during the operation
If mechanical faults were corroborated explaining the incident
If marking deficiencies fully explained the coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H8, H12, and H13 show crew members were physically present and reachable during the operation, supporting the claim. Discriminators favor communication breakdown over mechanical failure or marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in communication effectiveness despite physical presence

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_baseline_t3_prefinal phase is resistant to known defeaters.

assumptions: No direct evidence of mechanical/control failure was presented
Procedural deviations and communication issues are sufficient to explain the event
defeaters: If evidence showed verified hardware faults or bench checks confirming control malfunction
If communication failures were corroborated with hardware faults
If physical marking/location evidence was absent or ambiguous

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircrafts nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H10, H12) indicates the pushback continued past the TRP due to procedural decisions and lack of effective communication, not mechanical/control failure, contradicting resistance to defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting slow movement past TRP and lack of explicit mechanical fault confirmation

children_spec.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the aircraft's mechanical control components for presence and physical integrity; absence or damage would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are free from obstructions or blockages
children_spec.test_procedure: Check for any physical obstructions or blockages in the mechanical control pathways; detection of obstructions would reduce availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to control inputs
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify mechanical linkages and connections between control inputs and control surfaces; disconnections or misalignments would lower availability

children_spec.statement: Mechanical control components operate smoothly without excessive friction or binding
children_spec.test_procedure: Perform functional tests to assess smooth operation of mechanical controls; detection of friction or binding would reduce availability

children_spec.statement: Pushback crew was available at the scheduled time
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew scheduling and attendance records to confirm if the pushback crew was present at the scheduled time

children_spec.statement: Pushback equipment was operational and ready for use
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect maintenance logs and equipment status reports to verify if pushback equipment was functional and available

children_spec.statement: Communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were available and functioning
children_spec.test_procedure: Review communication system logs and test communication devices to confirm availability and functionality

node.statement: Crew members were not incapacitated or otherwise unable to respond to communication attempts

defeaters: If evidence showed crew were physically or cognitively incapacitated or unable to respond to communication attempts.
If there was a mechanical failure preventing response despite communication.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) shows crew members were communicating and aware but did not effectively respond to prevent the pushback past the TRP, contradicting the claim that crew were not incapacitated or unable to respond.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication attempts were fully effective or timely

node.statement: Pushback equipment was operational and ready for use

assumptions: No hidden mechanical faults occurred as none were reported
Communication described was effective and representative
TRP markings and environment were adequate as per personnel knowledge
defeaters: If evidence of equipment malfunction or control failure were found
If communication breakdown was documented causing the deviation
If environmental or marking deficiencies were proven to cause the incident

quotes.exact_quote: The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H8, H12) shows no mechanical failure and ongoing communication (H1, H2, H3) with known TRP markings (H7, H9, H13), supporting that pushback equipment was operational and ready, indicating procedural deviation rather than equipment fault or communication failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct bench check or equipment fault report provided; reliance on operator statements and observed behavior

node.statement: Pushback crew was available at the scheduled time

assumptions: Presence of tug instructor and trainee in tug at incident time implies availability at scheduled time
No evidence of mechanical failure or environmental issues causing the deviation
Communication was maintained as per evidence, so no breakdown preventing availability
defeaters: If evidence showed the crew was absent or unavailable at the scheduled time
If mechanical faults or environmental deficiencies were documented as primary causes
If communication breakdown was clearly demonstrated to prevent crew availability

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H9, H12) shows the pushback crew (instructor and trainee) were present and active at the scheduled time, supporting availability claim and favoring procedural deviation over mechanical failure, communication breakdown, or environmental deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct timestamps or explicit scheduling details; assumption that crew presence in narrative implies availability at scheduled time.

node.statement: Communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were available and functioning

assumptions: Communication via interphone and headset operator was effective and uninterrupted
No unreported communication issues occurred during pushback
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment was faulty or not used
If crew reported communication failures during pushback
If mechanical control faults were documented

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H11, and H12 directly indicate that communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were available and functioning, supporting the claim and favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown or mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication failure, but some assumptions about effective use of communication

node.statement: Mechanical components required for control are physically present and intact

assumptions: Mechanical components were inspected or would have been noted if faulty
Reported events and statements accurately reflect the absence of mechanical faults
defeaters: Evidence of physical damage or missing mechanical components required for control
Verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical failure
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates mechanical components were missing or damaged; all evidence points to procedural and communication issues (H1, H8, H10, H12, H13). Discriminators favor non-mechanical failure causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct inspection or fault code evidence for mechanical components

node.statement: Mechanical control components are properly connected and linked to control inputs

assumptions: Mechanical control components would be noted if faulty in the investigation history.
Absence of hardware fault reports implies proper mechanical control connections.
defeaters: Evidence of mechanical linkage faults or hardware malfunctions would change my mind.
Reports of control inputs not resulting in expected aircraft response would challenge this conclusion.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates mechanical control components were improperly connected or linked; history focuses on procedural and communication issues without hardware faults.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: Mechanical control components operate smoothly without excessive friction or binding

defeaters: Direct mechanical inspection reports or fault codes indicating friction or binding in control components
Bench checks or equipment fault traces showing mechanical control issues
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence directly addresses the mechanical control components' smooth operation or friction; all evidence relates to procedural, communication, or environmental factors.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

node.statement: Communication devices and channels were operational and accessible to the crew

assumptions: Operational and accessible communication devices imply functional communication channels.
No hardware faults affecting communication were reported.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication devices were malfunctioning or inaccessible to the crew, or if hardware faults were corroborated.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
Headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H11, and H12 indicate communication devices and channels were operational and accessible, supporting the claim that communication devices and channels were functional, favoring communication breakdown over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of any communication device failure, but some ambiguity remains about the effectiveness of communication despite operational devices.
